newsitem.title: LATVIA: KRISHTOPANS TO STAY, ATTACKS "WITCH HUNT".
newsitem.headline: KRISHTOPANS TO STAY, ATTACKS "WITCH HUNT".

text.p: Transport Minister Vilis Krishtopans on Monday said he would not resign although the prosecutor's office found he had broken anti-corruption laws.
Krishtopans also criticised the prosecutor's office and called for an end to what he called a "witch hunt" over the anti-corrption legislation.
Krishtopans said in a statement read at a news conference that it was no secret he had come to politics from business but now he felt he was fully a politician.
"I do not intend to resign as that would be a sign of weakness at a time when many people trust me and a sign of sins I have not committed," Krishtopans said.
He said he had not spoken with Prime Minister Andris Shkele but did not think the premier would ask for his resignation.
Krishtopans said he had never hidden his past business links and criticised the prosecutor's office.
"I think that the prosecutor's office should look into more serious things," Krishtopans said.
"I would like to call on all to stop this senseless witch hunt and devote more attention to things where one can see real corruption with the naked eye," Krishtopans added.
Several ministers have resigned amid the investigations under the anti-corruption laws, which mainly involves findings that people held official and business posts at the same time.
